Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Advancing In-vivo Chemical Imaging by Merging Synchrotron-Based Infrared Data, Rapid Spectral Image Analysis, and Quantitative Chemometrics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professors Carol J. Hirschmugl and Roshan M Dsouza of the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Professor Frank Vogt of the University of Tennessee Knoxville are supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry to conduct a collaborative project to advance in-vivo chemical imaging and analysis. The research will be conducted by combining synchrotron-based infrared data obtained with the hyperspectral imaging spectrometer (IRENI) at the Synchrotron Radiation Center at Madison, WI with rapid spectral image analysis using graphics processing units and quantitative chemometrics. The research involves high resolution imaging of live cells, scattering corrections, chemometric methods for concentration measurement in complex systems and application to algae growth studies.

If successful the project will improve the performance of IRENI, the premium facility of its kind, and enable the chemical imaging and analysis of samples that were previously considered to be too complex to handle, such as live cells. The project will have a broad impact in chemistry and biology. Students will be trained on a state-of-the-art infrared imaging instrument in a Synchrotron Radiation Center. Undergraduate students from diverse groups and their teachers will be involved in the project through existing REU and RET programs, and workshops will be conducted to familiarize the community with IRENI and to broaden its technical user base.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantitative chemical analyses of biological samples are especially challenging due to the huge number of compounds that contribute to the measured signals. While standard chemometric algorithms can handle unidentified analytes contained in calibration samples, they are unable to correctly predict concentrations when additional chemicals occur after the calibration. This, however, is a common situation in analyses of biological samples such as microalgae cells. It has been shown within this project that such cells sensitively adapt the chemical composition of their biomass to changes in their chemical ambience (e.g. nutrient concentrations) as well as in their biological environment (e.g. nutrient competitors). From an analytical point of view, this fact makes it essentially impossible to establish an appropriate calibration.

The core idea to ensure accurate and precise chemical analyses despite such hurdles is to broaden chemometric approaches from utilizing calibration concentration towards basing data models on calibration information. Information in addition to calibration concentrations can comprise concentration ranges or concentration ratios that are biologically reasonable or chemical insights about dynamic adaptation processes of (here) microalgae to shifting environments. Such additional information has been incorporated into innovative chemometric methodologies in form of regression constraints which then considerably reduce prediction errors caused by incomplete calibration sets.

In a first application, concentrations of 30 biologically relevant analytes contained in microalgal biomass could be predicted although the calibration did not and could not include nearly as many compounds that would have been mandatory for a reliable calibration based on conventional chemometrics. These novel methodologies have also been advanced towards nonlinear multivariate regression which was required to the model nonlinear responses of biosamples to shifting environments.

During these investigations, a computational challenge has been encountered and solved: Constrained regression and even more so nonlinear regression require considerably increased computation times compared to conventional linear chemometrics. The reason for this is that for an initial solution needs to be provided by the user which are searched for by means of a time-consuming pre-screening of high-dimensional parameter spaces. In order to narrow down the search range and to enable these screenings, first, probability distributions of model parameters are empirically derived that lead to a promising fit. In a second step, these distributions are then sampled in search for a good initial solution which is then iteratively optimized. In order to facilitate such screenings, algorithms have been developed which utilize multiple CPUs or multiple GPUs.

These innovations in chemometrics and their realization in novel software have enabled chemical analyses of complex samples. Furthermore, nonlinear modeling of sample - environment interactions allows gaining insights into the underlying mechanisms and not only deduce quantitative information but also explain the measured data. This has convinced the PI that conventional chemometrics has a restricted field of applications which can now be broadened considerably. He has shared this insight with the chemometric community in a Perspective article published in the Journal of Chemometrics which advocates broadening the scope of chemometrics.
